docs.lead_paragraph: I'm often asked about where independent workers and other self-employed people can get health insurance. I would like to hear from you, readers, about how you get your insurance. What kinds of policies are you choosing, and why? Where do you get it? What does it cost? If you have a resource to share, do it in the comments. If you want to write a longer note about your personal experience, e-mail me at heymarci@nytimes.com using the words "health insurance" in the header. I won't be able to reply directly to everyone, but I will read them all and promise to share what I learn in the column or blog.

headline.main: Friday's Links: Health Insurance for the Self-Employed

docs.abstract: Let's talk about health insurance for small business owners and the self-employed.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated Barack Obama dismissed an ad put out by Hillary Rodham Clinton that criticizes him for not agreeing to debate in Wisconsin. He says Mrs. Clinton is engaging in "the same old politics of phony charges and false attacks."

docs.lead_paragraph: Academics build entire careers trying to figure out why we vote the way we do, whether we make our decisions with our heads or our hearts. Right now, it's the hearts that are getting most of their attention, and two scholars who stress the role of emotions in political behavior, George Lakoff and Drew Westen, have become darlings of the Democratic party. People think with their guts, Westen says. Well, none of us really likes to believe that (is Westen thinking with his gut when he votes?), but what's a poor rationalist to do? Politics is hard. Consider health care.
